authors.name: Katharine Moss
authors.affiliation: UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology (UKCEH); University of Bristol

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ac6sa","text":"Bioorthogonal non-canonical amino acid tagging (BONCAT) is a method for detecting translational activity at the single cell level. Briefly, samples are incubated with a non-canonical amino acid which gets incorporated into newly synthesised proteins. Samples are fixed, then reagents are added to fluorescently tag the non-canonical amino acid in new proteins.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15erf","text":"BONCAT can then be combined with fluorescent activated-cell sorting (FACS) to sort the BONCAT active population from the total community. The sorted BONCAT active population can undergo DNA extraction for 16S rRNA sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1he","text":"This protocol is for river water and sewage effluent samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77t0m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clahc","text":"This protocol was developed by the UKCEH Molecular Ecology group. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d269k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
